item.title: Who Should the Oscar Nominees Be? Our Movie Critics Pick.
item.description: Here’s who our film critics Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson think voters should pick.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: In Sayre Gomez’s Art, L.A.’s Problems Move From Real to Hyper-Real
item.description: The city’s towering challenges include an abandoned skyscraper covered in graffiti. At David Kordansky Gallery, it inspires a tower of its own.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Griffin and Carlos Jaramillo
item.media:description: Sayre Gomez near his studio in Boyle Heights, a Latino neighborhood in east Los Angeles that often influences his art.

item.title: Golden Globes 2026: What to Expect From Sunday’s Awards Ceremony
item.description: Keep an eye on “One Battle After Another,” which is likely to dominate, and on the speeches. A particularly memorable one could be an Oscar lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene at a preview event for the Golden Globes, being held Sunday at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Judge Denies Salt-N-Pepa’s Attempt to Obtain Master Recordings
item.description: A federal judge agreed with Universal Music Group that the hip-hop act never owned the copyrights to its earliest work.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: Salt-N-Pepa has a Grammy Award and was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame last year.

item.title: How Wagner Moura Stayed True to Himself and Earned a Golden Globe Nomination
item.description: The Brazilian star of “The Secret Agent” is a major Oscar contender, though some at home turned against him for criticizing the right-wing government.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sela Shiloni

item.title: Bob the Drag Queen Is ‘Fully Obsessed’ With League of Legends
item.description: “I see why nerd culture is so exciting and fun,” said the “Drag Race” alum ahead of his Broadway debut in “Moulin Rouge.”
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck
item.media:credit: Amy Sussman/Getty Images for Mistr, Free Onl

item.title: Unpacking ‘People We Meet on Vacation’ with Emily Henry, Emily Bader and Tom Blyth
item.description: The author and the actors Emily Bader and Tom Blyth explain why the movie differs from the novel and raise the possibility of spinoffs.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer and Jennelle Fong
item.media:description: Henry said a lot of the actor casting suggestions gave her pause. “After Bader and Blyth were cast, she said, “that’s when I was like, ‘It’s going to be OK.’”

item.title: Bruno Mars, Robyn, Jill Scott and More: 8 Songs We’re Talking About
item.description: Bruno Mars, Jill Scott and Mandy, Indiana have new albums on the way, and a frantic tune from an anime film is No. 1 in Japan.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles

item.title: Washington National Opera Is Leaving the Kennedy Center
item.description: The opera, which has performed at the arts center since 1971, was concerned about declines in attendance and donations during President Trump’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Washington National Opera officials contend that exiting the Kennedy Center would also give it more control over programming decisions.

item.title: In the Path of a Raging Wildfire, a Luthier’s Precious Wood
item.description: Mario Miralles spent decades acquiring the spruce and maple for string instruments worthy of Yo-Yo Ma and Gustavo Dudamel. Then he was forced to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Michael Schmelling
item.media:credit: Michael Schmelling for The New York Times

item.title: Tom Verlaine Was a Mystery. His Archives Reveal More of His Story.
item.description: The Television frontman died in 2023, leaving behind boxes of music and notebooks that are now headed to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.category: New York Public Library for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: Verlaine grew up in New Jersey and Delaware, playing piano and saxophone before the Rolling Stones inspired him to pick up the guitar.

item.title: Mamdani Says Theater Should Not Be ‘a Luxury’ as He Hands Out Free Tickets
item.description: The mayor said a new initiative by the Under the Radar festival exemplified an arts affordability agenda that he intends to pursue.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.category: Brooklyn College, City University of New York
item.media:credit: Reece Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, with Kaneza Schaal and Meropi Peponides, right, co-creative directors of the festival, outside the Leonard and Claire Tow Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

item.title: 33 TV Shows to Watch This Winter: ‘Wonder Man,’ ‘Outlander’ and More
item.description: “Malcolm in the Middle”? “Scrubs”? Patrick Dempsey? In 2026, everything old is comfortable again.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.category: The Last Thing He Told Me (TV Program)
item.media:description: Zach Braff, top, and Donald Faison return for a revival of “Scrubs,” premiering Feb. 25 on ABC.

item.title: Will Arnett, Laura Dern and Bradley Cooper: 3 Friends Walk Into a Comedy Club
item.description: In many ways, their new relationship tale, “Is This Thing On?,” relies on their shared history over 25 years.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Sam Hellmann
item.media:description: Will Arnett, left, Bradley Cooper and Laura Dern mined their shared histories and foibles.

item.title: How Kit Harington Left Jon Snow Behind
item.description: The actor crashed after “Game of Thrones.” Now, as he returns in a new season of “Industry” on HBO, he feels like “one of the luckiest people alive.”
item.dc:creator: Miles Ellingham and Charlotte Hadden
item.media:credit: Charlotte Hadden for The New York Times

item.title: Bob Weir: 10 Essential Songs
item.description: The guitarist, singer and songwriter, who died at 78, cut his own path among his elders in the Grateful Dead, and beyond.
item.dc:creator: David Browne
item.media:description: Bob Weir sang on “Truckin’,” one of the Grateful Dead’s defining tracks.

item.title: Smithsonian Removes Label Noting Trump Impeachments
item.description: When the National Portrait Gallery replaced a portrait of President Trump this week, it took down a biography of his first term.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley, Robin Pogrebin and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: An earlier photograph of President Trump that hung at the National Portrait Gallery included lengthy wall text.

item.title: Paul Haggis Reaches $2 Million Settlement After 2022 Rape Verdict
item.description: A judge had ordered the Oscar-winning filmmaker to pay at least $7.5 million to a former film-industry publicist after a civil jury found him liable for raping her.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Paul Haggis, who won two Oscars for “Crash” (2004), had maintained that the sexual encounter was consensual.

item.title: Fetty Wap, ‘Trap Queen’ Rapper, Is Released Early From Prison
item.description: The Grammy-nominated singer was sentenced to six years in 2023 for drug trafficking. A representative said a bipartisan criminal justice law had enabled his release.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Fetty Wap pleaded guilty in 2022 to conspiracy to possess and distribute 500 grams or more of cocaine.

item.title: Timothy Busfield, Actor and Director, Is Accused of Child Sex Abuse
item.description: The Emmy Award-winning actor is accused of abusing two child actors while working on a television series. An arrest warrant was issued in New Mexico.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Timothy Busfield in Pasadena, Calif. in 2020.

item.title: Rare Comic Introducing Superman Sells Privately for $15 Million
item.description: The copy of Action Comics No. 1, published in 1938, was stolen from the actor Nicolas Cage in 2000 and recovered more than a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Andrew Wilson/Metropolis Collectibles Inc, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A copy of the comic that introduced Superman in 1938. Fewer than 100 copies are known to exist.

item.title: Bahram Beyzaie, Filmmaker Who Led Iran’s New Wave, Dies at 87
item.description: Despite a ceaseless battle against government censors, he was celebrated as one of his country’s greatest auteurs, winning praise from luminaries like Martin Scorsese.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: X Sues Music Publishers, Alleging ‘Collusion’ Over Licensing Deals
item.description: The social media platform says it was pressured into licensing agreements for songs “at inflated rates.” In 2023, publishers sued the company for copyright violations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Starting in 2021, Twitter, now known as X, had been exploring licensing deals with the major music conglomerates, but those talks stalled once Elon Musk took the platform over.

item.title: Jerome Lowenstein, 92, Dies; Teaching Doctor With a Literary Sideline
item.description: When not guiding students in a compassionate approach to patient care, he led a tiny publishing imprint that put out a much-rejected debut novel that won a surprise Pulitzer Prize.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Producers Guild Nominations Strengthen Oscar Odds for Five Films
item.description: “One Battle After Another,” “Sinners,” “Hamnet,” “Frankenstein” and “Marty Supreme” have now been recognized by all three major guilds.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.category: Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba Infinity Castle (Movie)

item.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include an elliptical Mexican anthology film, an experimental biopic of the writer Suzanne Césaire and more.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish

item.title: For 2hollis, Music Is a Family Business. So We Interviewed Him and His Dad.
item.description: The 22-year-old pop phenom’s father is John Herndon of the post-rock band Tortoise. They chatted about songwriting, nepotism and what they’ve taught each other.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli and Lucia Bell-Epstein

item.title: 8 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A Fairy Tale Opera Trades the Moral for the Mysterious
item.description: Matthias Pintscher’s first opera in 20 years invites audiences to find their own meaning in a macabre 19th-century tale.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Arlo Brown
item.media:description: Pintscher’s new opera, “Das kalte Herz,” is directed by James Darrah Black with stage design by Adam Rigg.

item.title: Think Punk Rockers Are Angry? Meet These Menopausal Women.
item.description: The BritBox show “Riot Women” follows an all-female band navigating the challenges of middle age — a subject that its creator, Sally Wainwright, knows well.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford
item.media:description: From left: Amelia Bullmore, Rosalie Craig and Tamsin Greig in “Riot Women.”

item.title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a film sequel to a beloved franchise and a documentary about the plight of polar bears.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman
item.category: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Last Straw (Movie)

item.title: How Americans Learned to Love Thomas Paine
item.description: His “Common Sense,” published 250 years ago, ignited the drive for American independence. That was hardly the end of the radical founder’s strange and winding story.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:description: Thomas Paine, whose 1776 pamphlet “Common Sense” helped spark the American Revolution, was hailed by some as the greatest radical of the age and reviled by others as a rabble-rousing atheist.

item.title: Read These 3 Books Before Watching the Movie
item.description: Jennifer Harlan, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, recommends three books to read before their film adaptation releases this year.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan, Edward Vega and June Kim

item.title: Gwyneth Paltrow’s Throwback Manicure Gets New Life in ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: Her press-on nails in the movie tell a deeper story.
item.dc:creator: Liana Satenstein

item.title: ‘Primate’ Review: Going Ape
item.description: This blood-splattered survival film about a rabies-infected chimpanzee is powered by unabashedly simple pleasures.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Hailee Steinfeld on ‘Sinners’ and What the Movie Taught Her
item.description: For the Ryan Coogler-directed vampire tale, “this character is what pushed me to sort of truly live in myself,” the actress said.
item.dc:creator: Brian Josephs
item.media:description: Hailee Steinfeld as Mary in “Sinners.” “This movie was a door I’ve been knocking on for a while,” she said.

item.title: Swoony Romance Books That Feel Like You’re on Vacation
item.description: Swoony reads will transport you from the doldrums of winter to a Caribbean resort, a Hamptons beach, the streets of Paris and more.
item.dc:creator: Ali Rosen
item.media:credit: The New York Times; author photo by Melanie Dunea

item.title: Riding the Roller Coaster Beat
item.description: Mekado Murphy, the assistant film editor for The New York Times, moonlights as the newspaper’s unofficial roller coaster correspondent.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Late Night Is Distracted by Kristi Noem’s Oversized Cowboy Hat
item.description: “Why is Kristi Noem always in some sort of cosplay outfit?” Seth Meyers asked on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2 Premiere Recap: The Doctors Will See You Now
item.description: Doctor Robby is back for one final shift before he goes on sabbatical. What could possibly go wrong?
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Season 2 of “The Pitt” opened by showing viewers a side of Dr. Robby (Noah Wyle) they hadn’t seen before.

item.title: ‘Bug’ Review: Carrie Coon Is Superb in an American Gothic Tale
item.description: Tracy Letts’s eerily topical, decades-old play about a woman’s descent into a world of conspiracy theories makes its nerve-rattling Broadway debut.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:description: Carrie Coon and Namir Smallwood in Tracy Letts’s stylistically slippery “Bug” at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘People We Meet on Vacation’ Review: When Stuffy Met Silly
item.description: Love grows between a restless travel writer and a contented homebody in this occasionally cute, instantly forgettable romantic comedy.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: John Wilson’s Enduring Art of Racial Politics and Personal Memory
item.description: “Witnessing Humanity” at the Met, with more than 100 artworks, and a gaze both inward and outward, is the artist’s first New York survey.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter

item.title: Amos Poe, New York’s No Wave Film Pioneer, Dies at 76
item.description: He documented the punk and post-punk music scene in the East Village, leading an independent film movement that was proudly unprofessional.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: 2026 Directors Guild Nominations: ‘One Battle,’ ‘Sinners’
item.description: The films of Paul Thomas Anderson and Ryan Coogler have been competing all season. Also in the running are Guillermo del Toro, Josh Safdie and Chloé Zhao.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Ron Protas, Polarizing Keeper of Martha Graham’s Legacy, Dies at 84
item.description: Graham, the great modern dance choreographer, named him her heir, setting off a bitter legal battle between him and the troupe she founded.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: Graham, Martha, Center of Contemporary Dance
item.media:credit: Ron Galella Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ron Protas with Martha Graham in 1984. Despite a lack of experience in dance or arts administration, Mr. Protas became her confidant and, after her death in 1991, artistic director of her dance company.

item.title: Stars of ‘The Pitt’ Gathered At HBO’s Premiere Party to Toast Season 2
item.description: At the premiere of Season 2 in Los Angeles, the cast and crew of HBO Max’s hyper-realistic medical drama learned the show would be renewed.
item.dc:creator: Juno Carmel and Alex Welsh
item.category: Sunset Tower Hotel (Los Angeles, Calif, Hotel)
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Magellan’ Review: The Beauty and the Bloodshed of a Smaller World
item.description: Gael García Bernal plays the explorer Ferdinand Magellan in Lav Diaz’s portrait of a brutal adventurer and his travels across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Greenland 2: Migration’ Review: The New World
item.description: Gerard Butler returns for more earthshaking action in this crowd-pleasing postapocalyptic thriller.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
item.description: Recent works by Gabriela Ortiz, choral music by David Lang and unreleased recordings by Radu Lupu are among our selections.

item.title: The Movie That Inspired Michael Mann to Direct
item.description: “The Joyless Street” is among the most chopped-up films of the silent era. A restoration at MoMA’s To Save and Project series proves eye-opening.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Can A.I. Match Molière’s Wit? These Researchers Think So.
item.description: Scholars and artists at Sorbonne University trained artificial intelligence to imitate the French playwright’s themes, structures and sense of humor. The result is a new play.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle
item.media:description: Actors from the Théâtre Molière Sorbonne rehearsing a scene from “The Astrologer, or False Omens.”

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Asks: Is TV Better in Small Doses?
item.description: The hospital drama has become the champion of a return to old-fashioned weekly viewing habits. But honestly, it makes a pretty great binge watch.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: Everything Happens at Once in Faith Ringgold’s Mini-Retrospective
item.description: A show highlights the artist’s extraordinary range with oil paintings, gouaches, figurines, textile works and ‘story quilts.’
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich

item.title: ‘Young Mothers’ Review: Teen Parents, Breaking Cycles
item.description: The Dardenne brothers’ latest film is a tender portrait of four teenage moms in a Belgian maternity shelter.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘OBEX’ Review: An Analog Nightmare
item.description: In this indie oddity boasting visceral D.I.Y. effects, a gentle loner enters the world of a video game to save his beloved dog.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘My Neighbor Adolf’ Review: The Nazi Next Door
item.description: The actors Udo Kier and David Hayman square off in this domestic drama where a man is convinced that his neighbor is Adolf Hitler.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Holding Liat’ Review: Hostage Situation
item.description: This unpredictable documentary follows a man and his family as they wait for news of his daughter and her husband, who were kidnapped in the Hamas-led Oct. 7, 2023, attacks on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold
item.media:description: Yehuda Beinin, left, and Tal Beinin in the documentary “Holding Liat.”

item.title: Can Shawn Levy Resuscitate ‘Star Wars’?
item.description: Lucasfilm hopes that Shawn Levy, who made “Deadpool and Wolverine” and helped make “Stranger Things,” can bring that same touch. The key may be his inner child.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:credit: Max Miechowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m the guy the studios call when they want someone they know will take their investment seriously and deliver responsibly,” Shawn Levy said.

item.title: ‘Dead Man’s Wire’ Review: When the Action Is Razor Thin
item.description: Dramatizing an odd news item from 1977, Gus Van Sant’s crime film isn’t crazy enough.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘All That’s Left of You’ Review: Hearts, Minds, History
item.description: The Palestinian American director Cherien Dabis offers eloquent context with her generational drama about Palestinian men.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: Convention-Defying in Life. In Art, Not So Much
item.description: “Carving Out History” offers the career highlights of Emma Stebbins, from the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park — a powerful symbol of hope and healing in “Angels in America” — to a standout sculpture of the woman she loved.
item.dc:creator: Arthur Lubow

item.title: Josh O’Connor’s Masterly 2025 Performances: ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’ and More
item.description: The star’s nuance and emotional power, along with his natural charisma, quietly enriched a quartet of movies in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)
